title: Acts Chapter 24 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 24 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 24 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 24.

questions.question: Who came down with the elders and the orator Tertullus to inform the governor against Paul?
questions.correctAnswer: Ananias the high priest
questions.explanation: Acts 24:1 states that Ananias the high priest descended with the elders and Tertullus to inform the governor against Paul.

questions.question: What did Tertullus say about the peace under Felix's governance?
questions.correctAnswer: They enjoy great quietness
questions.explanation: In Acts 24:2, Tertullus says they enjoy great quietness under Felix's providence.

questions.question: According to Tertullus, what sect was Paul a ringleader of?
questions.correctAnswer: The Nazarenes
questions.explanation: Acts 24:5 states that Paul was accused as a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes.

questions.question: What did the accusers say Paul was attempting to do to the temple?
questions.correctAnswer: Profane the temple
questions.explanation: Acts 24:6 says Paul was accused of attempting to profane the temple.

questions.question: Who took Paul away from the Jews with great violence?
questions.correctAnswer: Chief captain Lysias
questions.explanation: Acts 24:7 explains that Lysias took Paul away with great violence.

questions.question: How long had it been since Paul went up to Jerusalem for worship when he defended himself?
questions.correctAnswer: Twelve days
questions.explanation: Acts 24:11 states that it was twelve days since Paul went up to Jerusalem to worship.

questions.question: True or False: Paul admitted to causing a disturbance in the temple.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 24:12 says Paul was neither disputing in the temple nor raising up the people.

questions.question: What did Paul confess about his worship in his defense?
options: He worships the God of his fathers according to the way called heresy
He denies the law and prophets
questions.correctAnswer: He worships the God of his fathers according to the way called heresy
questions.explanation: Acts 24:14 shows Paul confessing that he worships God after the way which they call heresy.

questions.question: What hope did Paul say he has toward God?
questions.correctAnswer: The resurrection of the dead
questions.explanation: Acts 24:15 states Paul has hope toward God for the resurrection of the dead, both just and unjust.

questions.question: True or False: Felix immediately released Paul after hearing his defense.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 24:25-27 shows Felix delaying and keeping Paul bound for two years before Porcius Festus came.

questions.question: Who came with Felix when he sent for Paul to hear about the faith in Christ?
questions.correctAnswer: His wife Drusilla
questions.explanation: Acts 24:24 states that Felix came with his wife Drusilla when he sent for Paul.

questions.question: What was Felix's reaction when Paul reasoned of righteousness, temperance, and judgment to come?
questions.correctAnswer: Felix trembled
questions.explanation: Acts 24:25 states Felix trembled when Paul reasoned about those things.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul said he exercises himself to have always a conscience void of ______ toward God and men.
questions.correctAnswer: offence
questions.explanation: Acts 24:16 says Paul exercises himself to have a conscience void of offence toward God and men.

questions.question: True or False: Certain Jews from Asia found Paul purified in the temple with much tumult.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 24:18 states Paul was found purified in the temple neither with multitude nor tumult.

questions.question: What did Felix hope to receive from Paul, which made him send for Paul often?
questions.correctAnswer: Money
questions.explanation: Acts 24:26 explains Felix hoped to receive money from Paul to free him.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 24 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 24 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Paul's defense before Felix teach us about maintaining integrity under trial?
options: By having a conscience void of offense toward God and men
By avoiding all confrontations and accusations
By relying solely on human wisdom and eloquence
By refusing to answer any charges against him
questions.correctAnswer: By having a conscience void of offense toward God and men
questions.explanation: Paul states he exercises himself to have always a conscience void of offense toward God and men (Acts 24:16). This shows integrity under trial through a clear conscience and obedience to God and honest living among people (Acts 24:10-16).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with false accusations. Based on Acts 24, what biblical truth would you share about responding to such trials?
options: Respond calmly and respectfully, presenting the truth with confidence
Retaliate immediately with harsh words to defend yourself
Avoid all communication and run away from the situation
Accept guilt to avoid further conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Respond calmly and respectfully, presenting the truth with confidence
questions.explanation: Paul answered Felix calmly and respectfully, confidently explaining the truth of his actions without bitterness (Acts 24:10-13). He appeals to the governor's knowledge and justice rather than reacting in anger (Acts 24:22-24).

questions.question: What does the interaction between Felix and Paul teach us about the importance of spiritual readiness and timing?
options: Spiritual matters should be addressed promptly, but some delay may occur
It is best to postpone spiritual conversations indefinitely
Only officials can decide when to hear about faith
Spiritual discussions are irrelevant in daily life
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual matters should be addressed promptly, but some delay may occur
questions.explanation: Felix trembled while hearing Paul but deferred the conversation, saying he would call for him at a convenient season (Acts 24:25). This shows the need for readiness but also that sometimes spiritual growth unfolds over time (Acts 24:24-26).

questions.question: How does Acts 24 encourage believers to place hope in God's promises even amid difficulties?
options: By believing in the resurrection of the dead and living with hope
By focusing only on present comfort and ignoring future hope
By seeking power and wealth to overcome problems
By avoiding all trials through isolation
questions.correctAnswer: By believing in the resurrection of the dead and living with hope
questions.explanation: Paul confesses hope toward God, including belief in the resurrection of the dead, both just and unjust (Acts 24:15). This hope sustains believers in trials and encourages perseverance (Acts 24:14-16).

questions.question: According to Acts 24, what role does prayer and devotion to God play in a believer’s life during trials?
options: It helps maintain a clear conscience and inner peace
It is unnecessary because trials are only physical
It should only be done in public settings
It replaces the need for practical actions
questions.correctAnswer: It helps maintain a clear conscience and inner peace
questions.explanation: Paul’s desire to have a conscience void of offense (Acts 24:16) implies continual devotion and prayer to God to stay spiritually disciplined and peaceful amid challenges (Acts 24:10-16).

questions.question: How does the example of Paul bringing alms and offerings after many years teach believers about stewardship and generosity?
options: Faithfulness in giving supports the community even when it is inconvenient
Giving should only be done when others expect it
Generosity is unnecessary for spiritual growth
One should avoid giving to maintain personal wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness in giving supports the community even when it is inconvenient
questions.explanation: Paul came after many years to bring alms and offerings to his nation (Acts 24:17), showing consistent generosity and stewardship as an expression of faithfulness and love for others (Acts 24:17-18).

questions.question: A believer asks how to handle accusations without evidence. Based on Acts 24, what is the best biblical response?
options: Confidently present the truth and rely on God’s justice
Ignore all accusations and remain silent
questions.correctAnswer: Confidently present the truth and rely on God’s justice
questions.explanation: Paul confidently stated that his accusers could not prove the charges and appealed to Felix’s fairness (Acts 24:13, 24:10-16). This teaches trusting God’s justice and courageously standing for truth.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility and contentment can be learned from Paul’s willingness to be kept bound but treated with kindness?
options: Accepting difficult circumstances with humility while maintaining good relationships
questions.correctAnswer: Accepting difficult circumstances with humility while maintaining good relationships
questions.explanation: Felix kept Paul bound but allowed him liberty to receive visitors (Acts 24:23). Paul accepted this without bitterness, showing humility and contentment amid trials (Acts 24:27).

questions.question: True or False: Paul admitted to causing sedition and profaning the temple when accused before Felix.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Paul denied all accusations of sedition and profaning the temple, stating they could not prove these charges (Acts 24:5-6, 13). He maintained his innocence throughout his defense (Acts 24:11-13).

questions.question: True or False: Felix hoped to receive a bribe from Paul to secure his release.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The text states Felix hoped money would be given by Paul to release him, and therefore sent for him often (Acts 24:26). This reveals Felix’s corrupt motives.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul confessed that he worships God according to the way which they call ______.
questions.correctAnswer: heresy
questions.explanation: Paul confessed to worshiping God after the way which they call heresy, referring to the Christian faith that was misunderstood by his accusers (Acts 24:14).

questions.question: How does Acts 24 demonstrate the importance of honesty and transparency in church life and fellowship?
options: By openly addressing accusations and allowing examination of facts
By hiding faults to protect reputation
questions.correctAnswer: By openly addressing accusations and allowing examination of facts
questions.explanation: Paul invited examination and called for accusers to come forward with evidence (Acts 24:8, 19-20), showing transparency and honesty in dealing with church-related conflicts.

questions.question: Based on Acts 24, what biblical principle can be applied to evangelism and sharing the Gospel with those in authority?
options: Present the faith respectfully and with clear reasoning
Avoid discussing spiritual matters with officials
Only share faith with close friends
Use forceful arguments to convince others
questions.correctAnswer: Present the faith respectfully and with clear reasoning
questions.explanation: Paul reasoned about righteousness, temperance, and judgment to come with Felix, presenting the Gospel respectfully and thoughtfully (Acts 24:24-25).

questions.question: What does Acts 24 teach about perseverance through trials and imprisonment?
options: Continue faithfulness and maintain hope despite delays
Withdraw from community and stop serving
questions.correctAnswer: Continue faithfulness and maintain hope despite delays
questions.explanation: Paul was kept bound for two years but remained faithful, showing perseverance in trials and hope in God’s promises (Acts 24:27, 14-16).

questions.question: How does the chapter illustrate the role of marriage and family in spiritual influence?
options: Felix came with his wife Drusilla, a Jewess, showing family involvement in spiritual matters
Marriage is irrelevant to spiritual discussions
Only single people engage in faith
questions.correctAnswer: Felix came with his wife Drusilla, a Jewess, showing family involvement in spiritual matters
questions.explanation: Felix brought his wife Drusilla when he sent for Paul to hear about faith, indicating marriage and family can be contexts for spiritual instruction (Acts 24:24).

hard.title: Acts Chapter 24 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 24.

questions.question: Who accompanied Ananias the high priest when he descended to inform the governor against Paul?
questions.correctAnswer: Tertullus
questions.explanation: Ananias was accompanied by elders and a certain orator named Tertullus who accused Paul before the governor (Acts 24:1).

questions.question: What title is used to address Felix in Tertullus' speech, indicating respect and honor?
questions.correctAnswer: Most noble Felix
questions.explanation: Tertullus addresses Felix as 'most noble Felix' to show respect to the Roman governor (Acts 24:3).

questions.question: According to Tertullus, what sect is Paul accused of being a ringleader of?
questions.correctAnswer: The Nazarenes
questions.explanation: Paul is accused as a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes, a term used for early Christians (Acts 24:5).

questions.question: What action did the chief captain Lysias take regarding Paul, according to the accusations?
options: He took him away with violence
He judged him according to the law
questions.correctAnswer: He took him away with violence
questions.explanation: Lysias intervened with great violence to take Paul out of the hands of the Jews who wanted to judge him (Acts 24:7).

questions.question: What reason does Paul give for his presence in Jerusalem twelve days prior?
questions.correctAnswer: To worship
questions.explanation: Paul states he went up to Jerusalem to worship, refuting accusations of causing disturbances (Acts 24:11).

questions.question: Paul claims that neither in the temple, synagogues, nor the city was he found doing what?
options: Disputing or raising up the people
questions.correctAnswer: Disputing or raising up the people
questions.explanation: Paul asserts that he was not found disputing or causing disturbances in any place in Jerusalem (Acts 24:12).

questions.question: What confession does Paul make about his belief system before Felix?
options: He worships the God of his fathers according to the way called heresy
questions.correctAnswer: He worships the God of his fathers according to the way called heresy
questions.explanation: Paul confesses to worshiping God as his fathers did, following the way called heresy by some, referring to Christianity (Acts 24:14).

questions.question: What hope does Paul express that even his accusers allow?
questions.correctAnswer: The resurrection of the dead
questions.explanation: Paul speaks of hope toward God that there will be a resurrection of both the just and unjust, a belief his accusers allow (Acts 24:15).

questions.question: What does Paul say he exercises himself to maintain?
options: A conscience void of offence toward God and men
questions.correctAnswer: A conscience void of offence toward God and men
questions.explanation: Paul exercises himself to have a clear conscience before God and men, emphasizing moral integrity (Acts 24:16).

questions.question: What event involving Jews from Asia does Paul recount to Felix?
options: They found him purified in the temple without tumult
They accused him before the council
questions.correctAnswer: They found him purified in the temple without tumult
questions.explanation: Paul says certain Jews from Asia found him purified in the temple, neither with a multitude nor tumult (Acts 24:18).

questions.question: What single issue does Paul say he was called in question for during his trial?
options: Touching the resurrection of the dead
questions.correctAnswer: Touching the resurrection of the dead
questions.explanation: Paul states that the only accusation is about his teaching on the resurrection of the dead (Acts 24:21).

questions.question: How did Felix respond when Paul reasoned about righteousness, temperance, and judgment to come?
options: Felix trembled and deferred the matter
Felix became angry and imprisoned Paul
Felix ordered Paul to be flogged
questions.correctAnswer: Felix trembled and deferred the matter
questions.explanation: Felix trembled at Paul's reasoning but delayed the decision, saying he would call Paul at a convenient season (Acts 24:25).

questions.question: What motive did Felix have for frequently sending for Paul?
options: He wanted to convert to Christianity
He was curious about Jewish customs
questions.correctAnswer: He hoped for a bribe
questions.explanation: Felix hoped that Paul would give him money to secure his release, indicating a corrupt motive (Acts 24:26).

questions.question: What happened to Paul after two years when Porcius Festus succeeded Felix?
options: Felix left Paul bound to please the Jews
Paul was brought before the Sanhedrin
questions.correctAnswer: Felix left Paul bound to please the Jews
questions.explanation: Felix, wanting to please the Jews, left Paul in prison when Festus became governor (Acts 24:27).

questions.question: True or False: Felix allowed Paul to have visitors and did not forbid any acquaintance from ministering to him during his imprisonment.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Felix commanded a centurion to keep Paul but allow him liberty and visitors to minister to him (Acts 24:23).

theological.title: Acts Chapter 24 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 24 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who came to accuse Paul before the governor according to Acts 24?
options: Ananias the high priest, elders, and Tertullus
questions.correctAnswer: Ananias the high priest, elders, and Tertullus
questions.explanation: Acts 24:1 states that Ananias the high priest descended with elders and Tertullus to accuse Paul. This shows the official leaders opposing Paul, consistent with Old Testament patterns of religious leaders opposing God's messengers (e.g., Jeremiah 26:8-9).

questions.question: What accusation did Tertullus make against Paul?
options: He called Paul a pestilent fellow and mover of sedition
He claimed Paul denied the resurrection
He accused Paul of blasphemy against Caesar
questions.correctAnswer: He called Paul a pestilent fellow and mover of sedition
questions.explanation: Acts 24:5 describes Tertullus accusing Paul as a pestilent fellow and ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes, highlighting the charge of causing division. This reflects the opposition to the early church seen throughout Acts (Acts 17:6-7).

questions.question: How does Paul describe his faith in his defense before Felix?
options: He worships the God of his fathers, believing the law and prophets
He rejects the Jewish law and prophets
He denies the resurrection of the dead
questions.correctAnswer: He worships the God of his fathers, believing the law and prophets
questions.explanation: Acts 24:14 reveals Paul's confession that he worships the God of his ancestors and believes in all that is written in the law and prophets. This affirms continuity with Old Testament revelation (Deuteronomy 6:5; Isaiah 53).

questions.question: According to Paul, what hope does he have that the Jews also acknowledge?
options: The resurrection of the dead, both just and unjust
Eternal life only for the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: The resurrection of the dead, both just and unjust
questions.explanation: Acts 24:15 states Paul's hope in the resurrection of the dead, a doctrine also acknowledged by his accusers. This doctrine is rooted in Scriptures such as Daniel 12:2 and Isaiah 26:19, integral to biblical eschatology.

questions.question: What practice does Paul say he exercises to maintain a good conscience?
options: Having always a conscience void of offence toward God and men
Following only the traditions of men
questions.correctAnswer: Having always a conscience void of offence toward God and men
questions.explanation: Acts 24:16 shows Paul exercising himself to maintain a conscience void of offense, which reflects the biblical ethic of holiness and love for neighbor (Psalm 34:14; 1 Timothy 1:5).

questions.question: What reason does Paul give for being found purified in the temple?
options: He came to bring alms and offerings to his nation
He was protesting against the Roman government
He was teaching against the law
He was seeking to overthrow the high priest
questions.correctAnswer: He came to bring alms and offerings to his nation
questions.explanation: Acts 24:17-18 records Paul explaining he came to Jerusalem to bring gifts for the poor, consistent with Jewish customs of charity (Leviticus 25:35; Deuteronomy 15:7-8).

questions.question: What does Paul say about the accusations of evil against him while standing before the council?
options: No evil has been found against him except concerning the resurrection
He confesses to breaking the Roman law
He denies ever standing before the council
questions.correctAnswer: No evil has been found against him except concerning the resurrection
questions.explanation: Acts 24:20-21 reveals Paul stating that no charge of wrongdoing was found except the issue of resurrection, highlighting the centrality of this doctrine and the misunderstanding of his accusers (Job 19:25-27; John 11:25-26).

questions.question: How does Felix respond after hearing Paul’s defense about faith in Christ?
options: He trembled and said he would call for Paul at a convenient season
He condemned Paul without further hearing
He ordered Paul’s immediate imprisonment without trial
questions.correctAnswer: He trembled and said he would call for Paul at a convenient season
questions.explanation: Acts 24:25 records Felix trembling at Paul’s message on righteousness and judgment to come, indicating the convicting power of the gospel and the human response to divine truth (Romans 2:5; Hebrews 12:29).

questions.question: What was Felix’s underlying motive for frequently sending for Paul?
options: He hoped to receive money from Paul to release him
He sought to convert Paul immediately
He wanted to learn Greek philosophy
He was afraid of the Jewish leaders
questions.correctAnswer: He hoped to receive money from Paul to release him
questions.explanation: Acts 24:26 suggests Felix hoped for a bribe from Paul, reflecting the corruption sometimes present in political officials, as warned in biblical ethics (Exodus 23:8; Proverbs 17:23).

questions.question: What instruction did Felix give regarding Paul's custody?
options: To keep him guarded but allow him liberty and visitors
To imprison him in chains without visitors
To hand him over to the Jewish leaders
questions.correctAnswer: To keep him guarded but allow him liberty and visitors
questions.explanation: Acts 24:23 shows Felix ordered Paul to be guarded but allowed freedom to receive friends, indicating a balance between custody and respect for Paul's rights (Acts 16:37).

questions.question: What was the occupation of Tertullus who accused Paul?
questions.correctAnswer: Orator
questions.explanation: Acts 24:1 mentions Tertullus as a certain orator, signifying a skilled speaker used historically in legal proceedings (Nehemiah 8:8).

questions.question: What did Lysias the chief captain do when the Jewish leaders tried to judge Paul according to their law?
options: He took Paul away by force
He allowed them to judge Paul
He sent Paul to the Sanhedrin
questions.correctAnswer: He took Paul away by force
questions.explanation: Acts 24:7 explains that Lysias intervened with violence to rescue Paul, demonstrating Roman authority superseding local religious courts (John 19:12; Luke 23:38).

questions.question: What was Paul accused of profaning?
questions.correctAnswer: The temple
questions.explanation: Acts 24:6 accuses Paul of attempting to profane the temple, a serious charge reflecting concerns for holiness in Jewish worship (2 Chronicles 29:5; Malachi 3:1).

questions.question: How long had it been since Paul went up to Jerusalem to worship before these accusations?
questions.correctAnswer: Twelve days
questions.explanation: Acts 24:11 states Paul had been in Jerusalem only twelve days, emphasizing the recentness of his temple visit and his innocence of the charges.

questions.question: Who succeeded Felix as governor, resulting in Paul remaining bound?
questions.correctAnswer: Porcius Festus
questions.explanation: Acts 24:27 records that after two years, Porcius Festus replaced Felix and left Paul bound, showing the political transitions affecting Paul's imprisonment (Daniel 6:16; Luke 23:14).
